Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Downside of Perseverance--Investigating and Moving Students Beyond Unproductive Persistence

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project researches persistence in mathematics learning in a computer-based learning environment (CBLE). The research investigates how a CBLE can provide the supportive help and promote the self-regulatory strategies necessary for students to be not just persistent, but productively persistent math learners. The project will focus on the middle school years, an important and vulnerable point in the school trajectory, as mathematical concepts become increasingly difficult and abstract in the transition from arithmetic to algebra. Persistence is critical in CBLEs. Research shows has shown that changing student academic mindsets can have strong benefits for their persistence and achievement. Sustained effort is important but not always sufficient for learning and less attention has been paid to the downside of perseverance, called wheel-spinning, the time that struggling learners spend without making progress. The project will build instrumentation, theory, and intervention strategies to address the needs of struggling math students. For technology designers, the project will distill findings to develop research-based design principles for CBLEs. For educators, the project will translate findings into pedagogical approaches that can be used to enhance teacher practice.

The research is designed to address three goals: (1) Develop automated detectors that can differentiate between wheel-spinning and productive persistence in real time; (2) Investigate student, teacher, and system factors that predict wheel-spinning and productive persistence; and (3) To design and test interventions to reduce wheel-spinning and promote productive persistence. The project will use detailed log data from thousands students who use an existing computer-based mathematics program. Learning analytic methods now provide the means to identify and study micro-level student behavioral engagement patterns. The project will use complementary data analytic, correlational, think-aloud, and experimental methods to examine productive persistence and its understudied yet common counterpart, unproductive persistence. The research will advance the state of the art in data mining-based measurement to provide instrumentation that can be used to enhance learning; extend empirical findings about the cognitive and self-regulatory processes that enable productive persistence in math learning; and extend the empirical base informing what supports in CBLEs or teacher practice are necessary for productive persistence. The project, supported through the EHR Core Research (ECR) program of fundamental research in STEM, will contribute important research findings regarding STEM learning and learning environments, which are important priorities of the ECR program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The importance of persistence in becoming proficient in math is widely acknowledged, and research has shown that changing students’ academic mindsets can have strong benefits for their persistence and achievement. Not all perseverance is necessarily productive, however, and can lead to what has been called “wheel spinning”, a state in which a student persists for too long without making progress. We undertook this project, “The Downside of Perseverance--Investigating and Moving Students Beyond Unproductive Persistence,” to investigate ways to detect and support students who are engaged in wheel spinning in an online learning system.

 

The project focused on middle school education, an important and vulnerable point in students’ school trajectories. At this point mathematical concepts become increasingly difficult and abstract as students transition from arithmetic thinking to algebraic thinking. 

 

Our investigations of wheel spinning were undertaken in the context of ASSISTments, a computer-based learning environment that supports teachers in assigning classwork or homework while generating robust reports of student performance and providing students real time feedback as they work. The randomized controlled trials used to support this project were conducted within Skill Builders, mastery-based problem sets in ASSISTments that require students to accurately answer three consecutive problems in order to complete the assignment. Study content was developed using E-TRIALS, infrastructure that connects researchers with ASSISTments’ content and user base and allows for the experimental manipulation of normal instructional practices while providing detailed reports on student and class level outcomes.

We observed outcomes related to each of the project’s three key goals: 

  1. To develop automated detectors that can differentiate between wheel-spinning and productive persistence,

  2. To explore what student factors and learning environment factors are associated with productive persistence, and

  3. To design and test interventions to reduce wheel-spinning and promote productive persistence.

 

We were successful at developing automated detectors that can differentiate between wheel spinning and productive persistence, and in particular we were able to differentiate these groups relatively early in the learning process (as early as three problems into the learning sequence). Accuracy in differentiating wheel spinning students from non-persistent students grew with the number of problems. We found that the most accurate detectors of wheel spinning were based on a combination of human-engineered features and machine learning models; this hybrid approach was more accurate than detectors created by human engineering or machine learning alone. These findings will allow for continued research into the detection of when students are engaging in wheel spinning, with the goal of providing appropriate supports to those students. 

 

We conducted a series of teacher-developed randomized controlled trials to explore the potential reasoning underlying wheel spinning, in comparison to productive persistence, and their effects on student performance. Results from these pilot studies helped to reveal that those who were wheel spinning often made errors based on a misconception, resulting in their repeating the same error across multiple problems. This insight led to the design of short, targeted feedback messages meant to address the specific errors students had made, thereby providing an opportunity to reflect on the errors before moving on to the next problem in a set. In the process of generating these findings, we also discovered that students with faster attrition, or those who dropped out of problem sets earlier, tended to exhibit low self-confidence in the assignment topic.

 

To design and test interventions to reduce wheel-spinning and promote productive persistence we identified two key math topics in 7th grade and, based on existing Skill Builders of these topics, created two sets of resources that used visual representations (number lines) to provide students with feedback related to answers associated with common misconceptions. In one set, when a student answered using a misconception, we simply provided a visual explanation of the correct answer. In the other set, we provided a visual example of what we called “consequences of actions” in which the student’s incorrect answer was included in the visual feedback, allowing the student to see how their response led to an incorrect result. We conducted two randomized controlled trials to examine the effects of these visual representations on improving student learning outcomes when compared to ASSISTments’ standard correct/incorrect feedback (i.e., not tailored to misconceptions). The set of resources that provided a visual explanation of the correct answer showed no differences when compared to the control (correct/incorrect) feedback. However, the “consequences of actions” feedback showed positive differences, including reaching mastery in significantly fewer questions than the control group, performing better on the next question, and requesting fewer hints. However, there was no difference between treatment and control on the proportion of students who achieved mastery.

 

To disseminate project outcomes our teams have published five papers and presented at four conferences. We continue to pursue dissemination opportunities, with one paper in submission and one in progress.
